awd_titl_txt: 2020-2024 Provision of log data reduction and database services for scientific ocean drilling

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
FINAL REPORT / PROJECT OUTCOMES

The goal of this project conducted at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (LDEO) from 2020-2025 was to provide the scientific community with 1) data reduction and quality control of current International Ocean Discovery Program (IODP) well log data acquired aboard the JOIDES Resolution (JR), and other scientific ocean drilling platforms, 2) online data access of both current and historical logging data, 3) web services that allow for automated query and retrieval of well log data from the online database (LogDB). LDEO has worked closely with the US, European and Japanese Science operators, and with Schlumberger, to ensure that the log data collected and distributed by IODP is as consistent as possible across all platforms and to provide shipboard and shore-based scientists with the best final data products possible. These data sets are accessible through LogDB web services and can be used with consistency for comparison and integration with core and seismic data from each IODP expedition. In addition to the online LogDB relational database, LDEO has published historical well log data in the LogDB community area through Zenodo, an external citable and public online repository that has been selected by JRSO for publication of the core data from IODP.

During the 2020-2024 period, LDEO performed data reduction and QA/QC for 41 new IODP holes drilled by the JOIDES Resolution, corresponding to over 20 km of drilled and logged intervals.  During the same period, LDEO performed QA/QC on 2 expeditions drilled by D/V Chikyu for IODP-CDEX/MarE3 (Expeditions 358 and 405), corresponding to over 3 km of drilled and newly logged intervals during these programs. All data are password-protected and remain restricted under moratorium for one year after the end of an expedition. At the end of the moratorium period, data are released to the wider scientific community and freely accessible through the LogDB web interface. 

The LogDB online database now includes data from IODP Expeditions 301-403, as well as IODP-ESO Expeditions 302, 310, 313, 325, 347, 364, and 381 and IODP-CDEX/MarE3 Expeditions 314, 319, 322, 332, 337, 338, 343, 348, 358 and 405 (at the end of moratorium periods). To date, data from 692 scientific drilling holes logged during the DSDP, ODP, IODP-1 and IODP-2 programs have been uploaded to and are maintained in LogDB. This comprehensive dataset corresponds to ~340 km of drilled and logged intervals and includes more than 40,000 individual data files. The current size of LogDB is about 600 GB for DSDP/ODP/IODP logging data, plus an additional 100 GB for logging data from other scientific research programs. All post-moratorium LogDB online data and related documentation are publicly searchable and accessible through the LogDB web interface at the following URL: http://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/logdb/scientific_ocean_drilling/.

Data reduction of standard and image logs under this award utilized the PC-based TechLog software, which is the primary Schlumberger-supported log processing platform licensed to LDEO/Columbia University for both basic and advanced analysis all types of well logs, images, and sonic waveform data. Format conversion of all data (to ASCII, binary, SEG-Y, GIF, and NetCDF formats) was performed with scripts developed at LDEO.

During the 2020-2024 period, LDEO has maintained and expanded the web page interface for LogDB to enable user-defined data searches of IODP logging data and meta-data, as well as documentation about field data collection, tool descriptions, data reduction and processing utilities, plotting tools, and QA/QC assessment for logging data from Scientific Ocean Drilling. These web links include tool descriptions (https://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/research/technology) that describe data collection technology, processing (https://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/log-data-processing/), correlation with coring and field operations (https://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/data/timeline/), graphical functions for visualization of logging data (https://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/data/logplot/), and seismic correlation function for data integration (https://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/synthetics/).

For final data archiving associated with this award, by the end of performance period, LDEO published all LogDB data for DSDP/ODP/IODP programs in the external Zenodo repository (zenodo.org), including all historical expedition data and each subsequent expedition at the end its moratorium period. Logging data from these programs will be will available:

  • DSDP (87 holes)
  • ODP (382 holes)
  • IODP data (231 holes as of 6/30/2025)

In addition, LDEO submitted an archival set of raw and processed digital logging data from LogDB along with associated metadata records to the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) in the Stennis Space Center, MS (https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/).

 


Last Modified: 04/16/2025
Modified by: David S Goldberg

FINAL REPORT / PROJECT OUTCOMES

In addition to the online LogDB relational database, LDEO has published historical well log data in the LogDB community area through Zenodo, an external citable and public online repository that has been selected by JRSO for publication of the core data from IODP.


During the 2020-2024 period, LDEO performed data reduction and QA/QC for 41 new IODP holes drilled by the JOIDES Resolution, corresponding to over 20 km of drilled and logged intervals. During the same period, LDEO performed QA/QC on 2 expeditions drilled by D/V Chikyu for IODP-CDEX/MarE3 (Expeditions 358 and 405), corresponding to over 3 km of drilled and newly logged intervals during these programs. All data are password-protected and remain restricted under moratorium for one year after the end of an expedition. At the end of the moratorium period, data are released to the wider scientific community and freely accessible through the LogDB web interface.


The LogDB online database now includes data from IODP Expeditions 301-403, as well as IODP-ESO Expeditions 302, 310, 313, 325, 347, 364, and 381 and IODP-CDEX/MarE3 Expeditions 314, 319, 322, 332, 337, 338, 343, 348, 358 and 405 (at the end of moratorium periods). To date, data from 692 scientific drilling holes logged during the DSDP, ODP, IODP-1 and IODP-2 programs have been uploaded to and are maintained in LogDB. This comprehensive dataset corresponds to ~340 km of drilled and logged intervals and includes more than 40,000 individual data files. The current size of LogDB is about 600 GB for DSDP/ODP/IODP logging data, plus an additional 100 GB for logging data from other scientific research programs. All post-moratorium LogDB online data and related documentation are publicly searchable and accessible through the LogDB web interface at the following URL: http://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/logdb/scientific_ocean_drilling/.

Format conversion of all data (to ASCII, binary, SEG-Y, GIF, and NetCDF formats) was performed with scripts developed at LDEO.

These web links include tool descriptions (https://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/research/technology) that describe data collection technology, processing (https://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/log-data-processing/), correlation with coring and field operations (https://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/data/timeline/), graphical functions for visualization of logging data (https://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/data/logplot/), and seismic correlation function for data integration (https://mlp.ldeo.columbia.edu/synthetics/).

ODP (382 holes)
IODP data (231 holes as of 6/30/2025)



In addition, LDEO submitted an archival set of raw and processed digital logging data from LogDB along with associated metadata records to the National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI) in the Stennis Space Center,MS (https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/).
